dc:description:
The *KCNJ13* gene was first reported in relation to autosomal recessive Leber congenital amaurosis in 2011 (Sergouniotis et al., PMID: 21763485), following a 2008 study linking the gene to autosomal dominant cases of snowflake vitreoretinal degeneration (Hejtmancik et al., PMID: 18179896). Cases reported as Leber congenital amaurosis 16 or vitreoretinal dystrophy generally had onset ranging from birth to early adulthood and showed severely decreased electroretinogram responses from both rods and cones, severe decrease in central visual acuity and constriction of peripheral visual field, nyctalopia, nystagmus, early onset cataracts, moderate myopia, fibrosis over the optic discs, and abnormalities of the retinal vasculature such as retinal arteriolar constriction, retinal neovascularization, and/or vitreous hemorrhage. Cases described as snowflake vitreoretinal degeneration exhibited some similar features such as early onset cataracts, moderate myopia, and dysmorphic optic discs, but generally showed onset in the second decade of life or later. They additionally showed distinct features such as snowflake-like retinal deposits, focal retinal pigment epithelium degeneration, reduced macular function, reduced scotopic b-wave, corneal guttae, and increased risk of retinal detachment. Per criteria outlined by the ClinGen Lumping & Splitting Working Group, cases of snowflake vitreoretinal degeneration were found to be distinguishable by both their molecular mechanism (a monoallelic missense variant p.Arg162Trp resulting in nonselective cation current causing cell depolarization) and mode of inheritance (autosomal dominant), in comparison to the biallelic loss-of-function mechanism of autosomal recessive Leber congenital amaurosis 16. While the two conditions share some overlapping phenotypic features, heterozygous carriers from recessive families have so far been found to be unaffected (PMID: 21763485, PMID: 35477418). Therefore, cases of Leber congenital amaurosis or other retinopathies caused by biallelic *KCNJ13* variants have been recommended for splitting into the present curation under a disease entity referred to as KCNJ13-related recessive retinopathy. *KCNJ13* will be curated separately for autosomal dominant snowflake vitreoretinal degeneration.

This curation has scored eight suspected disease-causing variants (five missense and three nonsense), which have been collectively reported in seven probands in six publications (PMID: 21763485, PMID: 25921210, PMID: 25475713, PMID: 31647904, PMID: 27203561, PMID: 32783370). All probands included in this curation harbored two variant alleles within the *KCNJ13* locus, with only one being compound heterozygous (PMID: 27203561). Six probands were homozygous with two known to have consanguineous parents (PMID: 21763485, PMID: 25475713). The mechanism of pathogenicity appears to be biallelic loss of function, characterized in some cases by nonsense variants predicted to trigger absence or decrease in the amount of the gene product (PMID: 21763485, PMID: 25475713, PMID: 27203561). These publications did not contain families with a sufficient number of affected family members to evaluate segregation evidence. A small number of additional cases were available, but were not included in the curation as they shared genotypes with previously scored probands (PMID: 25475713, PMID: 31647904).

This gene-disease association is also supported by experimental evidence that *KCNJ13* is highly expressed in the retinal pigment epithelium (RPE), and to a lesser degree in retina and small intestine (PMID: 30239781). *KCNJ13* encodes a potassium channel (also known as Kir7.1) that localizes to long apical membrane extensions or microvilli of RPE cells (PMID: 28878288) and allows intracellular potassium ions to flow out into the subretinal space to maintain normal potassium levels during photoreception (PMID: 23255580). Biallelic disruption of the *KCNJ13* ortholog in *obetd15* zebrafish results in late-onset retinal degeneration, retinal thinning with loss of the RPE and photoreceptor layers, and vascular abnormalities including wider retinal blood vessels and fibrotic material at the optic discs (PMID: 31647904). While mice with biallelic *Kcnj13* knockout are not viable, conditional knockout in RPE cells results in severe retinal degeneration with loss of the photoreceptor layer and abnormal RPE morphology and function, extinguished electroretinogram a-waves and b-waves, and some attenuation of retinal blood vessels (PMID: 35096838). Mice harboring a nonsense variant from a human patient in RPE cells showed reduced amplitude in the electroretinogram c-wave originating from the RPE that could be partially rescued by subretinal injection of sgRNA to restore the wild-type allele through CRISPR/Cas9-based editing (PMID: 37561581). Additional data from model organisms and rescue experiments were available but not included in the curation, as the maximum scoring from this evidence type had already been reached.

In summary, *KCNJ13* has a Definitive association with KCNJ13-related recessive retinopathy. This has been repeatedly demonstrated in both research and diagnostic settings and has been upheld over time without the emergence of contradictory evidence. This classification was approved by the ClinGen Retina Gene Curation Expert Panel on April 3rd, 2025 (SOP Version 11).

evidence.dc:description: NM_002242.4(KCNJ13):c.431T>C (p.Leu144Pro) is a missense variant that has no experimental evidence in this study.

evidence.rdfs:label: Méjécase_2020_Family_6_Proband_6-1
evidence.detectionMethod: The proband was previously genotyped by a next-generation sequencing panel, followed by Sanger sequencing-based confirmation.
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: The proband received a diagnosis of severe early onset retinal dystrophy. The fundus appearance was described as consistent with KCNJ13-retinopathy
evidence.previousTestingDescription: The proband was previously genotyped by a next-generation sequencing panel.

evidence.dc:description: Up-scoring has been recommended due to functional data indicating that the variant has almost no residual function, and due to the study's report of a similarly affected but reportedly unrelated family with the same homozygous genotype. Down-scoring has been recommended due to the homozygous state of the variant and the potential for unknown consanguinity.

NM_002242.4(KCNJ13):c.458C>T (p.Thr153Ile) is a missense variant that has no experimental evidence in this study but has separately been shown to be expressed and localized properly with almost no potassium conductance and failure to hyperpolarize the membrane potential (PMID: 35584325, Figure 1I).

evidence.rdfs:label: Toms_2019_Proband_A-1
evidence.detectionMethod: The proband was previously genotyped by next-generation sequencing focused on an LCA gene panel. Sanger sequencing of the KCNJ13 gene was subsequently performed for confirmation.
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: The proband received a diagnosis of Leber congenital amaurosis. The optic disc abnormalities consisted of diffuse severe early leakage associated with prior fibrosis along arcades and disc. Cataracts were a complication of surgeries for a vitreous hemorrhage.
evidence.previousTestingDescription: The proband was previously genotyped by next-generation sequencing focused on an LCA gene panel.

evidence.dc:description: Despite the prediction that the variant will evade nonsense-mediated decay, the prediction of a severe (>50%) C-terminal truncation is sufficient to up-score the variant.

NM_002242.4(KCNJ13):c.496C>T (p.Arg166Ter) is a nonsense variant in exon 3 of 3 that is not predicted to trigger nonsense-mediated decay but rather to truncate the C-terminal 54% of the protein product.

evidence.rdfs:label: Sergouniotis_2011_Proband_A-2
evidence.detectionMethod: The proband was initially genotyped by a combination of homozygosity mapping and exome sequencing. Sanger sequencing of the proband and family members was then performed to confirm the presence of the variant and to test segregation.
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: The proband received a diagnosis of Leber congenital amaurosis shortly after birth. Fundoscopy results were described as "significant pigment at the level of the retinal pigment epithelium and in a configuration unlike that of typical RP".
evidence.previousTestingDescription: The proband was initially genotyped by a combination of homozygosity mapping and exome sequencing.

evidence.dc:description: NM_002242.4(KCNJ13):c.359T>C (p.Ile120Thr) is a missense variant that has not been studied at the functional level. Moderate up-scoring has been recommended based on the study's report of an apparently unrelated patient (also Saudi) with a similar phenotype harboring the same variant in the homozygous state.

evidence.rdfs:label: Khan_2015_Proband
evidence.detectionMethod: The proband was initially genotyped by next-generation sequencing focused on a panel of 27 LCA genes and 60 recessive retinitis pigmentosa genes. Sanger sequencing of the proband and family members was then performed to confirm the presence of the variant and to test segregation.
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: The proband's overall phenotype was summarized as "juvenile cataract in the setting of a congenital vitreo-retinal dystrophy notable for fibrosis over the disc and clumped pigmentation in the posterior pole". The authors comment that the phenotype should be described as; "early-onset vitreo-retinal degeneration (with early-onset cataract)" rather than as LCA, due to the presence of vitreous degenerative changes as well as the ERG being recordable in patients in the second decade of life and beyond.
evidence.previousTestingDescription: The proband was initially genotyped by next-generation sequencing focused on a panel of 27 LCA genes and 60 recessive retinitis pigmentosa genes.

evidence.dc:description: NM_002242.4(KCNJ13):c.314G>T (p.Ser105Ile) is a missense variant that has no experimental evidence in this study regarding its potential impact on the protein product.

NM_002242.4(KCNJ13):c.655C>T (p.Gln219Ter) is a nonsense variant in exon 3 of 3 that is not predicted to trigger NMD but rather to truncate the C-terminal 39% of the protein product. Down-scoring has been performed due to the limitations of the genotyping method.

evidence.rdfs:label: Perez-Roustit_2017_Proband
evidence.detectionMethod: The proband was previously genotyped by screening for ABCA4 variants, followed by Sanger sequencing of the KCNJ13 exons and intron-exon boundaries.
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: The proband received a diagnosis of Leber congenital amaurosis. His phenotype included increased retinal thickness and presence of hyper-reflective formations around the optic disc and periphery. Visual impairment was severe but did not evolve significantly during the first 30 years of age.
evidence.previousTestingDescription: The proband was previously genotyped by screening for ABCA4 variants.

evidence.dc:description: Up-scoring has been considered to take into account the functional data, while down-scoring has been performed to account for the homozygosity and potential for unknown consanguinity.

Heterologous expression of the NM_002242.4(KCNJ13):c.158G>A (p.Trp53Ter) variant in CHO-K1 cells revealed that the variant channel retained very little ability to enable the flow of current, with the measurement of -68.8pA more comparable to the negative control (-42.4pA) than to the wild-type control (-588.7pA).

evidence.rdfs:label: Pattnaik_2015_Proband
evidence.detectionMethod: The proband was initially genotyped by PCR-based screening for known LCA-associated variants and next-generation sequencing focused on a 19-gene LCA panel. Sanger sequencing of gaps and low-coverage regions as well as for confirmation of the variants detected by other methods.
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: The proband has been diagnosed at different times with Stargardt disease, retinitis pigmentosa, cone-rod dystrophy, and Leber congenital amaurosis, first presenting with night vision difficulties at age 2 years. Small focal sub-RPE deposits were observed.
evidence.previousTestingDescription: The proband was initially genotyped by PCR-based screening for known LCA-associated variants and next-generation sequencing focused on a 19-gene LCA panel.

evidence.dc:description: Default scoring is considered appropriate as the variant has convincing experimental evidence of a severely deleterious effect, but also needs to be moderately down-scored for homozygosity.

NM_002242.4(KCNJ13):c.722T>C (p.Leu241Pro) is a missense variant that has no experimental evidence in this study but has separately been shown to severely decrease expression and abolish complex glycosylation of KCNJ13 (PMID: 30257863, Figure 10).

evidence.rdfs:label: Sergouniotis_2011_Proband_B-3, male
evidence.detectionMethod: The proband was previously genotyped by screening for previously-reported LCA-causing variants by microarray chip, with no molecular diagnosis. Sanger sequencing of the KCNJ13 exons and intron-exon boundaries was subsequently performed.
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: The proband received a diagnosis of Leber congenital amaurosis. His phenotype is described as similar to the other affected individuals, including "a distinct and unusual retinal appearance and a similar early onset of visual loss, suggesting both impaired retinal development and progressive retinal degeneration, involving both rod and cone pathways". The disease was described as mildly progressive. OCT showed distorted retinal microanatomy even in areas without cell death, possibly indicating disturbance of the early development of the neurosensory retina.
evidence.previousTestingDescription: The proband was previously genotyped by screening for previously-reported LCA-causing variants by microarray chip, with no molecular diagnosis.

evidence.dc:description: The model features a missense mutant that does not correspond to a known variant from human patients. On the other hand, the combination of photoreceptor degeneration and vascular abnormalities are a good match to the human patients and may provide additional insights into the mechanism of disease.

The 12-month-old zebrafish showed late onset retinal degeneration with retinal thinning and retinovascular abnormalities that included wider blood vessels and the presence of fibrotic material at the optic discs (Figure 4).
evidence.rdfs:label: The obetd15 zebrafish is a Kcnj13 mutant.

evidence.dc:description: Default scoring is considered appropriate as the mouse model matches the mode of inheritance and many of the phenotypes of the human probands.

The 6-month-old mouse with induced Cre recombinase shows loss of photoreceptor cell layers (Figure 4F) and severe retinal degeneration (Figure 4G) relative to the control lacking Cre (Figure 4E), but with relative preservation of retinal morphology near the optic nerve. The RPE layer in the Cre-positive knockout cells shows irregular and flattened cell shapes with abnormal nuclear and cytoskeletal morphology relative to the control (Figure 5D). The knockout mouse fundus shows distinct inclusions, especially in the outer segment, as well as some attenuation of retinal blood vessels (Figure 6). ERG a-waves and b-waves are also extinguished (Figure 7A), consistent with loss of the entire photoreceptor layer (Figures 4F, 5B). There was also low amplitude of c-waves originating from the RPE cells (Figure 7C) that could be restored by lentiviral transduction of the functional *KCNJ13* gene (Figures 7C, 7D).
evidence.rdfs:label: Conditional Kcnj13 knockout in mice

evidence.dc:description: Down-scoring was considered since the rescued phenotypes represent a subset of the overall course of disease. However, similarities to the analogous RPE65 rescue experiment (also partial rescue) led to default scoring.

The ERG c-wave from the RPE layer shows 55% higher amplitude for the edited/targeted retina relative to the non-targeted control (Figures 6J and 6K) and is accompanied by intact retinal structure by OCT (Figures 6H and 6I).
evidence.rdfs:label: CRISPR/Cas9-based rescue of patient variant in the mouse RPE

evidence.dc:description: Default scoring is recommended due to the relevance of this biochemical function to RPE cell survival and photoreception.

Inward rectifier potassium channel activity (specifically in the context of allowing intracellular K+ to flow out of the RPE into the subretinal space adjacent to the photoreceptor cells to maintain normal extracellular K+ levels during photoreception) is relevant to RPE cell survival. It may also reverse the effects of the potassium flow in neuronal cells following depolarization.
evidence.rdfs:label: The KCNJ13 channel controls potassium flow out of the RPE.

evidence.dc:description: Default scoring is considered appropriate, as the RPE and retinal expression of the KCNJ13 transcript is highly specific relative to the levels in other tissues.
The EyeIntegration v2.12 dataset shows that KCNJ13 is highly expressed in the RPE, and to a lesser degree in retina and small intestine tissues.
evidence.rdfs:label: KCNJ13 is highly specifically expressed in RPE and retina.
